I agree with Colin's approach of setting the fitness to some very 
low value;  you can just ignore the outputs if they don't stabilize.
But also note that to make meaningful comparisons with other 
people's XOR results, you should technically disable the ability for 
NEAT to add recurrent connections.  That's because no one tries to 
solve XOR with a recurrent network- they always use feedforward 
solutions.  It's kind of interesting that NEAT finds a recurrent 
solution, but it ruins comparisons with other methods since they 
don't have the ability to do that so it isn't really fair.  I 
disabled the addition of recurrent connections for my XOR 
experiments.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, cgreen@d... wrote:
> Quoting Karl Lewin <lewinke67@y...>:
> 
> > From the FAQ:
> > ************
> > How do I ensure that a network stabilizes before
> > taking its output(s) for a classification problem?
> > ...
> > Note that output may not always stabilize in some 
> > cases.
> > ...
> > ************
> > 
> > What are peoples thoughts on handling this? 
> > 
> > I've tried both:
> > 
> > 1. Iterate until output stabilizes or N iterations 
> > have been performed. (N=10 or 100) 
> > 
> > 2. Same as 1 but if it doesn't stabilize by N 
> > iterations set output to the maximally wrong value.
> > 
> > For the XOR problem if I use the first method the best
> > 
> > network tends to have this structure:
> > 
> > 0       1        2
> > \       |       /
> >  \      |      /
> >   \     |     /
> >    \    |    /
> >     \   |   /
> >      \  |  /
> >       \ | /
> >        \|/
> >         3--\
> >         |  |
> >         \--/
> > 
> 
> Hi Karl,
> 
> Interestingly I think this is the same structure I posted on the 
list not long 
> ago, but the output oscillated between high and low values and 
only gave the 
> correct answer after exactly two iterations of the network. Anyway 
back to the 
> question - very simply, if the network does not stabilize within N 
iterations 
> then my XOR experiment assigned a fitness of zero. 
> 
> 
> Colin.
